title: Autumn Leaves

musicalLanguage.description: The most-played jazz standard in the world. Written by Joseph Kosma in 1945 with French lyrics by Jacques Prevert, English lyrics by Johnny Mercer. The harmonic progression — a descending cycle of fifths through the relative major and minor — is the skeleton key to jazz harmony. Learn this and you've learned the language.
musicalLanguage.structure: AABC form (32 bars in the real book). This arrangement covers the A section — the iconic 8-bar chord cycle that every jazz musician knows by heart, played twice with variation.
keyMoments: Measures 1-2: Cm7 to F7 — the ii-V in Bb major. The melody starts on C5 and steps down.
Measures 3-4: Bbmaj7 to Ebmaj7 — the I and IV of Bb major. The warm center of the progression.
Measures 5-6: Am7b5 to D7 — the ii-V in G minor. The harmony darkens, pulling toward the minor home.
Measures 7-8: Gm — arrival. The whole cycle resolves here. G minor is home.
Measure 9: The second pass begins — same chords, new melodic choices.
teachingGoals: The ii-V-I progression — the most common chord movement in jazz. Cm7-F7-Bbmaj7 is ii-V-I in Bb major.
Left hand voicings: rootless or shell voicings (3rd and 7th) with the root implied
Right hand melody: stepwise motion with occasional leaps, always landing on chord tones
Swing feel: eighth notes are not even. The first eighth is longer, the second shorter (triplet feel).
The circle of fifths: Cm7→F7→Bb→Eb→Am7b5→D7→Gm. Each root falls a fifth.
styleTips: Swing the eighths. If it sounds straight, it's not jazz.
The left hand chords should be quiet — comping, not competing with the melody
Don't rush. Jazz breathes. Leave space between phrases.
The D7 to Gm resolution (measures 5-8) is where the emotion lives. Let it pull.
Think of the melody as a story being told, not notes being played

measures.teachingNote: Cm7 chord. The melody climbs stepwise from C5 to F5 — a simple ascending line that outlines the chord. Left hand plays C (root), Eb (minor 3rd), Bb (7th) — a shell voicing. This is the ii chord in Bb major.
F7 chord — the V of Bb major. The melody settles on Eb5 then D5, both chord tones of F7 (7th and 6th). Left hand: F (root), A (3rd), Eb (7th). The tritone A-Eb wants to resolve.
Bbmaj7 — the I chord. We've arrived at the tonic of the relative major. The melody rises D5 to G5, reaching the highest point. Left hand: Bb (root), D (3rd), A (7th). This is home in the major key.
Ebmaj7 — the IV chord. The melody rests on F5 and Eb5. The harmony is bright and warm. Left hand: Eb (root), G (3rd), D (7th). The major key area feels spacious.

Am7b5 — the ii chord of G minor (half-diminished). The melody descends from Eb5 down to Bb4 — the mood darkens. Left hand: A (root), C (minor 3rd), G (b7th). This is the pivot — we're leaving Bb major and heading to G minor.

D7 — the V of G minor. The tension peaks. A4 is the 5th of D7, Bb4 is the b13 — dark, pulling. Left hand: D (root), F# (major 3rd), C (b7th). The F# is the sharpest sound in the piece — it demands resolution to G.
Gm — home. The resolution. G minor after the long journey through the cycle of fifths. The melody gently ornaments around G4 and Bb4. Left hand: G (root), Bb (minor 3rd), D (5th). Rest here. Breathe.
Gm continues — the melody rests on G4, then silence. This space before the second pass is essential. Jazz is as much about what you don't play.
Second time through — Cm7 again. The melody starts the same but with eighth-note pickup, adding motion. This variation is what makes jazz: same chords, different story each time.
F7 again — but the melody descends further this time, reaching A4. More eighth notes, more motion. The melody is becoming more conversational.
Bbmaj7 — the melody rises with an eighth-note pickup. Bb4 to F5 — a wider arc than the first time. The harmony opens up.
Ebmaj7 — the melody turns downward with eighth notes, settling on Bb4. More ornamented than the first pass.
Am7b5 — the descending line C5 to G4 over the half-diminished chord. Each note is a chord tone or tension. The pull toward G minor intensifies.
D7 — the melody touches F#4 (the 3rd of D7) before resolving upward through G4 to A4. The F# leading tone pulls to G with magnetic force.
Gm — final resolution. The melody arpeggios through G minor: G4, Bb4, D5, Bb4. A fuller, more confident ending than the first time through.
Final G minor chord — the melody holds G4 as a whole note while the left hand builds upward: G2, Bb2, D3, G3. The harmony fills out and the piece settles into stillness.

source: Arrangement: AI Jam Session. Based on Autumn Leaves by Joseph Kosma (1945).
